A writer in tho Literary Gszstie in noticing
Mrs. Opie's IllUs!rsti.rs al Lyrs " has the fol-
lowing remarks, which We recommend to The atten-
tion Of parents -


Thete is one class Of lies. which are little
surprised did not airact . larger share Of Mrs.
Opies attention; lies told by parentst 10 their chill
dren. We believe that the slight regard in which
strict truth is held among mankind. is principally
owing to the lies which arc told 10 children BY their
parents during the lew FIRST years OF their lives


hen is the time that permanent impressions :aay
re as well made as any later period. 1t is them
probably, that what is called the natural propensity
OF child is unfoIced. Many persons rho haze
great abhorrencs Of lying, and Whip their children


they detect them in 1t. yet make no scrupfe of tel
iing and acting to them the most atrocious false
hoods. There ave few parents who do not do this
in greater lesser degree, though doubtless with
out dreaming they are guilty of criminal deception.
With many the whole business OF managing their
children is piece OF mere ar6ce and trick. They
are cheated in their amusements, cheated 10 their
ood, cheated in their dress Lies are told them 10
get them to do any thing which is disagreeable. II
a child is to axe physc, the mother tells him she
has something good for him to drink; if recusan,,
she says she will send for the doctor to cut off his
ears or pull his teeth, that she will go away snd
leave him, and thousand things OF the same kind,
each Of which may deceive once and answer the
present purpose, but will invariably fail afterwards.
Parents are too apt to endeavor to pacify their
children BY making promises that they never intend
to perform. II they wish, for instance to take away
some ea,abe which they fear will be injurious, they
reconcile them by the promise of ride. or walk,
or something else which will please them, but with
OUT any intention OF gratifying them.


This is lying. downright lying. People think
nothing of breaking their promises to children, ii
the performance be not perfectly convenient But
they are the las, persons to whom promises should
be broken, because they cannet comprehend the
reason, if there be one, why they are not kept.
Such promises should be scrupulously redeemed,
though at q great Inconvenience, and even when in
adver,en,ly made. For The chiid's moral habit is
of infinitely more consequence than such an incon
venience can be TO parent.


We have only noticed few Of The eases Of lying

MEDICAL NOTICE.

Professor Carter, 10 one of his las, letters from


Genoa, describes his visit the birth place of the


Discoverer Of America, in the following terms -
/ 4" A full day was occupied in an excursion 10 Co


coletto, the reputed birthplace Of Christopher Co


lumbus. Although much obscurity still hangs over


the cradle OF this great man, yet the American
| eer in particular, will feel a satisfaction in visiting


spot which tradition has associated with The Dis.


coveref Of the New World. l have neither time nor
inclination at present to enter into dlsquistion
upon the contradictory authorities in relation this
subject nor to balance the conflicting claims Of ri
val places TO the nativity of the adventurous nsvga.
tor His own manuscript is now understood to be
in the hands Of Washington Irving at Madrid, who
perhaps may throw some new light upon the early
years OF its author.


The village Of Cccoleto is situated al the head Of
the Gulf about fifteen miles from Genoa. on the
road towards Savona. On arriving at the little no
tel, inquiry made for the house OF Christopher
Columbus; and some hall dozen villagers who
seemed to exu in the name, led the way to the
sque and humble mansion. 1t stands upon the sea


shore, cled by the Alps and looking south upon
a waste Of waters.


II the grandeur Of ofnatural scenery can inspire ge
MUS, and awaken young thought to noble pursuits,
Cocole.lo may hence draw argument TO strength
her claim. and in this particular at least challenge
| competition. The low, arched ceilings aud decay
ed walls bear all the marks OF great age; but one
can hardly bring himself to the belief, that they
have stood between thtee and four centuries. A
small chamber, perhaps len feet square, is shown,
in which it is pretended Columbus was born Ma
| ny fragments OF the ceiling have been carried away


al slcs. The furniture OF the room looks as if it
| might be coeyal with the apartment. litte i'm
age of the Madonna, cross, and cup for the
holy water. suspended from the curtain at the
head OF The bed. The present tenaD, is kind
hearted woman, who spread her frugal board and


insisted sharing its hospitality with the strangers
| from distant land, which her illuslrious preccccs
sor had discovered Her ideas OF cosmogrsphy
| we're not precise, and like many other less pardona
pe Europeans, she seemed 10 consider. all Ameri
cans, as the descendants of the Aborigines.
| In front Of the house is small terrace, over
hanging the shore; and when the Gulf is aormy


and the waves run high, shower Of spray patters


upon he roof If this was really the birth place Of


Columbus, it may almost be said, that he was cra
died upon the sea- the first sounds he heard must


have been its murmurs, and the first object of his


vision, its blue expanse. As stood leaning over


the balusuade, watching the swels breaking at my


feet, and the line OF little boats moored along the
| beach. increduity for moment vanished, and ina


gination pictured the juvenile navigator, launching


his adventurous bark, and sporting with that ee.


mcn, which was desllned to conduct him TO imper
,shsbe renown."

In July last meeting Of the Architects and
Builders Of the University OF Virginia, held meet
ing, and resolved to ask permission to erect suta
BILE Monument TO the m.mor, Of THOMAS JET
FERSON. Cap, John M Perry. and James
Dinsmore, Esq. were appointed committee TO com
municate the wishes Of thar meeting to the Execu
tor. and to obtain his appreciation The following
are copies Of the letter of the Committee and OF
the Executors reply.


University Of Iirginia, July asth, 1926.
DEAR SIR,-It becomes our duty to send you
the enclosed resolutions. and earnestly to solicit
your kind scquiescence therein. We would esteem
il envahe privilege to be permitted to perfo' m
with our own hands the las. sad tribute Of esteem
and affection 10 he memory of him whose depar.
ture we so deeply lament--as the organ through
which this request comes in behalf OF those for
whom speak as we'll ss for ourselves we cannot
withhold the expression of our sincere sympathy
in your domestic Affections aud our INDIVIDUAL grief
for the loss Of this great and good man. The con-
nc xion existing for several years past between him
and ourselves in the erection Of this restitution,
(his best monumenD afforded US daily oppoftuni-
ties Of admring the active beneyolence Of his heart
and the constant exer,ions of his great mind for the
advancement Of the future glory and happiness Of
his country-hers too, the may fayois and acts Of
personal kindness, which. in the discharge Of our
duties. he always cheerfully extended towards us,
could but create. as they did, the best affections for
his memory. Your early attention to this will, dear
sir. be thankfully acknowledged by us--and in the
mean time offer you the assurance of our re
spect and esteem.


John NJ. PERRY,


JAMES DlNSMORE.
T. J. RANpoEPH, Esq, Tuition.


Tnfton, .aug. 9TH, 1926.
Messrs. John M. Perry, and James Dinsmore-


GENTLEmEn.--I have this day received your ltt-
ter Of the 28h, covering resolutions entered into On
the 27lh Of July, by the underakers and builders OF
the University. Zwas proposing, as you had heard,
From the Central Gazette, Jan. a7.

to children, but enough to illustrate the frequency
Of it. And yet, after having pursued = course Of
deception for the two three frst years Of life, il
the parent then finds his child is trying 10 deceive
him, and will tell downright lie, he wonders how
he should have learned to do so, for he has always
taught him to speak the truth without rejecting
that he has been lying to him from his very birth.
So he attributes that habit to an innate disposition
and tendency for falsehood, which he has himself
been fostering and nourshing from the frat.

WINCHESTER, A. Fep. 3, I6T.


Fire! The Barn and Corn. house Of Mr.. Uarid
Timbe,iake of this county, was destroyed by hre
on Wednesday, the s9'h Of January, with upwards
of three Thousand bushels Of grain. The lire was
communicated by negro boy Of about twelve years
Of age, who, on hearing one Of the family read an
account OF the late distressing fire at Alexandria,
expressed a great desire to see such one, and,
taking coal, proceeded with H. unoosessea 10 the
harm, and threw Il in. MIR. Timberake's loss is
tma,ed al upwa,ds Of four thousand dollars and 10
The second severe one which he has sustained by
The SANE destructive slsmeut, within afew years.
WINCHESTER. VA. Feb. 9, 1897.

With love, whose heart did glow.
All for this maid of forty five,


Who had treated him--sew SEN!
"Ah wilt thou be my duck y quoth Jem.
Says she "'twould be no use,
For me TO be tailot's duck,


I'd rather be his goose! %
"Oh cruel Peg !" cried Jenny Stitch,
Of all my hopes the root;
My hear, is cur by loves sharp shears,
Oh do not scorn my suis ~
But loves warm breath, it could could not thaw
This forty five Yeas frost;
Says she, " Your hopes arc like your legs,
They're made foi to be crossedi
And soon poor Stitch, he waxed thin,
His coats like shirts did 81,
Quoih he, "If should 60 off now
'Fwoud not be in a .ftt'
He sickened f:lst--his pulse was low.

lie tried little cabbagei

BY reason OF this Peggy Green,
Hho was his aspl in a.vii
He loved her quite as ardently,
But with as little use--
He wore Peg stuck IN his heat,
Aud pcgs stuck in his shoesi
"My love-" cried he. " for Peggy Green
Il knows of no control
Her name is written in my heart,
And craven on my sole
He ST. he'd in yain--she fouted him,
Her ,corn he deeply felt,
Like i1oWers killed by cruel frost,
lie soon began to rveh,
Now when she saw their love so true
To choose she knew no, which;
Three days she nothing did hut think
The fourth day saw her Stitch,
And now It was not long before


Uar heard the woetul news,
That Jenny Stitch his rival was,
standing in his shoes
His heart was broke, when he saw things
Had come TO such pass;
any days are numbered now !" sigh'd he.
Sand near me is my iassn
In vain to him the doctors did
Their pills and physic send:
lie failed apace-his eyes grew dim.
And nearer ward his end
'A.lack a-day" he cried, i" is She
To me forever lost
cannot-cannut give up Peg"
And then gave up the ghost
Now vi, Stitch and Mrs Stitch
Inc ieased in jo, and riches
And soon forgot poor Willy Wax,
Whilst making Gftis sGchesi

CONDITIONS OF THE WATCHMAN

to discharge to the remains OF my Grandfather
The last OF those melancholy personal duties, which
devolyed his relative, friend and Executor
and who, of all men living, loved him most. had
proposed myself in the discharge of this duty to
have strictly followed that form which he had inti-
mated 10 me- as being most agreeable to him,
simple atd unostrntatious index OF the spot where
his remains were deposited suited to the crcum
stances Of his family, OF stone; that the fu
tute proprietor might not be tempted to destroy il
Tor the value OF the materials on the grave plain
die or cube Of three feet without any nouldnpss
surmounted by an obelsk Of six feet, each of sim
gle stone. On the faces of the obsiisk. the fol-
lowing inscription, and not word more.


HERE WAS BURIED


THOMAS JEFFERSON,
Author OF the Declaration OF American IndepeRs
dence, of the Statutes of Virginia for Religious
Freedom, and Father Of the University Of Vir-
ginia.


On the die:


BoRN. ApRtL 2, l743, o. S.


DIED, JULY 4, 1926.
BY these, as testimonials that he had lived, he
desired most to be remembered. In compliance
with your very gratifying wishes upon the subjecss
aud knowing the long and cordial feelings of kind
ness which had existed between yourselves and my
excellent and beloved parent, l resign cheerfully
to your more skfu hands this last act of our per-
sonal services Accept for yourselves the assurance
OF my klndest esteem.


Very respectfully,


THO: J. RANDOLPH,
JOHN NJ. PERRr, and


JAMEs DINsMoRs, Esqrs.


Near the University.

.Niw Fork, Feb 6-sevcrsl respectable ind,id-
uals in this city have purchased Of land In
the island of Cuba. for the purpose OF forming
settlement there. and associated themselves under
The title Of the Company # .Noa. In order to faci
lilae their views they have applied to the Ltgish-
ture Of this state for act of incorporation under
The above title. We observe BY the Legislative
proceedings that their application has bees before
the House, where it has met with some opposition,
but as we think, under erroneous impressions as to
the objects of the company We understand from
coed authority, tha, the settlement at Moa is not
only patroniEed by the local authorities of Cuba.
but 10 made with express reference, and in conlor-
nifty to decree Of the King OF Spain, Of October
2lst, 1917, the title Of which explains its object
:" Real Cedula sobrs aumentar Ia pottacion biance
de Ia Ista de Cuba': that is. Royal Decree on
the subject Of increasing the trhite population of The
Island OF Cuba.''


Ono ground of opposition, as 1t appears by the
debate reported in the Albany papers, vas that The
granting Of the application would encourage negro
slavery. The views OF the association have been
entirely misconstrued. So far from this being the
fact, the company neither own, nor intend ever to
own single slave. The climate Of Moa is uneom-
monty temperate, and it has been proved by expo
rence that uhite man can pei iform bodily labor
there. with little danger to his health in this
state. One Of the principal objects of the Company
is to demonstrate by actual experiment that the
land can be cultivated uithout the labor Of btackss
and to set an example, which, if followed through
out the island will deprive The monsters who traffic
in human flesh, Of their principal market.


". T. GaS.


North West Passage - In letter from Mr..
Douglas, the botanist to DR.. Hooker, dat. d from
the Great Falls on the Columbia river, the 24th Of
March, 1923, there is the 10 lowing curious para.
graph respecting the North West Passage:


There is here Mr.. Macleod, who spent the
last Ave years at Fort Good Hope, on the Macken-
zie river. He informs me that it the natives with
whom he 10 perfectly acquainted. are worthy Of
credit there must be North West Passage. They
describe very large river that runs parallel With
The Mackenzie, and falls into the sea near Icy
Cape, at the mouth of which there is an establish
me nj on an island where ships come to trade. They
assert that the people there very wicked, having
hanged several of the natives 10 the rigging they
wear their boards long. Some rclianoe, should
think. may be laid on their satemen as Mr.. Macleod
showed US some Russian coins, combs, ard several
articles Of hardware, very different from those fur
nished by the British Company. MIR. Macleod
caused the natives to assemble last summer, tor the
purpose of accompanying him in his departure for
Hudson's Bay. The sea is said 10 be open alter
July. This gentieman's conduct affords striking
example of the effects of perseverance. In the
short space Of eleven months, he visited the Polar
Sea- and the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, undergo
ing such hardships and dangers as perhaps, were
never experienced by any other individual"

Thete is one class Of lies. which are little
surprised did not airact . larger share Of Mrs.

dren. We believe that the slight regard in which
strict truth is held among mankind. is principally
owing to the lies which arc told 10 children BY their
parents during the lew FIRST years OF their lives


hen is the time that permanent impressions :aay
re as well made as any later period. 1t is them
probably, that what is called the natural propensity
OF child is unfoIced. Many persons rho haze
great abhorrencs Of lying, and Whip their children


they detect them in 1t. yet make no scrupfe of tel
iing and acting to them the most atrocious false
hoods. There ave few parents who do not do this
in greater lesser degree, though doubtless with
out dreaming they are guilty of criminal deception.
With many the whole business OF managing their
children is piece OF mere ar6ce and trick. They
are cheated in their amusements, cheated 10 their
ood, cheated in their dress Lies are told them 10
get them to do any thing which is disagreeable. II
a child is to axe physc, the mother tells him she
has something good for him to drink; if recusan,,
she says she will send for the doctor to cut off his
ears or pull his teeth, that she will go away snd
leave him, and thousand things OF the same kind,

present purpose, but will invariably fail afterwards.
Parents are too apt to endeavor to pacify their
children BY making promises that they never intend
to perform. II they wish, for instance to take away

reconcile them by the promise of ride. or walk,
or something else which will please them, but with
OUT any intention OF gratifying them.


This is lying. downright lying. People think
nothing of breaking their promises to children, ii
the performance be not perfectly convenient But
they are the las, persons to whom promises should
be broken, because they cannet comprehend the

insisted sharing its hospitality with the strangers

sor had discovered Her ideas OF cosmogrsphy
| we're not precise, and like many other less pardona
pe Europeans, she seemed 10 consider. all Ameri
cans, as the descendants of the Aborigines.
| In front Of the house is small terrace, over
hanging the shore; and when the Gulf is aormy


and the waves run high, shower Of spray patters


upon he roof If this was really the birth place Of


Columbus, it may almost be said, that he was cra
died upon the sea- the first sounds he heard must


have been its murmurs, and the first object of his


vision, its blue expanse. As stood leaning over


the balusuade, watching the swels breaking at my


feet, and the line OF little boats moored along the
| beach. increduity for moment vanished, and ina


gination pictured the juvenile navigator, launching


his adventurous bark, and sporting with that ee.


mcn, which was desllned to conduct him TO imper
,shsbe renown."

full articles.headline: From the Central Gazette, Jan. a7.
full articles.article:
In July last meeting Of the Architects and
Builders Of the University OF Virginia, held meet
ing, and resolved to ask permission to erect suta
BILE Monument TO the m.mor, Of THOMAS JET
FERSON. Cap, John M Perry. and James
Dinsmore, Esq. were appointed committee TO com
municate the wishes Of thar meeting to the Execu
tor. and to obtain his appreciation The following
are copies Of the letter of the Committee and OF
the Executors reply.


University Of Iirginia, July asth, 1926.
DEAR SIR,-It becomes our duty to send you
the enclosed resolutions. and earnestly to solicit
your kind scquiescence therein. We would esteem
il envahe privilege to be permitted to perfo' m
with our own hands the las. sad tribute Of esteem
and affection 10 he memory of him whose depar.
ture we so deeply lament--as the organ through
which this request comes in behalf OF those for
whom speak as we'll ss for ourselves we cannot
withhold the expression of our sincere sympathy
in your domestic Affections aud our INDIVIDUAL grief
for the loss Of this great and good man. The con-
nc xion existing for several years past between him
and ourselves in the erection Of this restitution,
(his best monumenD afforded US daily oppoftuni-
ties Of admring the active beneyolence Of his heart
and the constant exer,ions of his great mind for the
advancement Of the future glory and happiness Of
his country-hers too, the may fayois and acts Of
personal kindness, which. in the discharge Of our
duties. he always cheerfully extended towards us,
could but create. as they did, the best affections for
his memory. Your early attention to this will, dear
sir. be thankfully acknowledged by us--and in the
mean time offer you the assurance of our re
spect and esteem.


John NJ. PERRY,


JAMES DlNSMORE.
T. J. RANpoEPH, Esq, Tuition.


Tnfton, .aug. 9TH, 1926.
Messrs. John M. Perry, and James Dinsmore-


GENTLEmEn.--I have this day received your ltt-
ter Of the 28h, covering resolutions entered into On
the 27lh Of July, by the underakers and builders OF
the University. Zwas proposing, as you had heard,

to children, but enough to illustrate the frequency
Of it. And yet, after having pursued = course Of
deception for the two three frst years Of life, il
the parent then finds his child is trying 10 deceive
him, and will tell downright lie, he wonders how
he should have learned to do so, for he has always
taught him to speak the truth without rejecting
that he has been lying to him from his very birth.
So he attributes that habit to an innate disposition
and tendency for falsehood, which he has himself
been fostering and nourshing from the frat.

WINCHESTER, A. Fep. 3, I6T.


Fire! The Barn and Corn. house Of Mr.. Uarid
Timbe,iake of this county, was destroyed by hre
on Wednesday, the s9'h Of January, with upwards
of three Thousand bushels Of grain. The lire was
communicated by negro boy Of about twelve years
Of age, who, on hearing one Of the family read an
account OF the late distressing fire at Alexandria,
expressed a great desire to see such one, and,
taking coal, proceeded with H. unoosessea 10 the
harm, and threw Il in. MIR. Timberake's loss is
tma,ed al upwa,ds Of four thousand dollars and 10
The second severe one which he has sustained by
The SANE destructive slsmeut, within afew years.

bliss Peggy Green seamatress was,

Though forty.fvc and drying fast.
She still remained Greeni
Was she accomplished '-could she play
Upon the Plano
Speak French--Italian-do You aski

No wonder then, that lovers two


For her in sorrow wasted
Long seepless ngh,s-for grevouslg
Their hearts Miss Green had 6a,tedG
Jem S'ch--ihe tailor Che was onc,)
With love, whose heart did glow.
All for this maid of forty five,


Who had treated him--sew SEN!
"Ah wilt thou be my duck y quoth Jem.
Says she "'twould be no use,
For me TO be tailot's duck,


I'd rather be his goose! %
"Oh cruel Peg !" cried Jenny Stitch,
Of all my hopes the root;
My hear, is cur by loves sharp shears,
Oh do not scorn my suis ~
But loves warm breath, it could could not thaw
This forty five Yeas frost;
Says she, " Your hopes arc like your legs,
They're made foi to be crossedi
And soon poor Stitch, he waxed thin,
His coats like shirts did 81,
Quoih he, "If should 60 off now
'Fwoud not be in a .ftt'
He sickened f:lst--his pulse was low.
Distress his cheeks did rayage;
He ate ma food, now and then
lie tried little cabbagei
Will Wax the cober, pinel for her.
He too, grew THU and small,
BY reason OF this Peggy Green,
Hho was his aspl in a.vii
He loved her quite as ardently,
But with as little use--
He wore Peg stuck IN his heat,
Aud pcgs stuck in his shoesi
"My love-" cried he. " for Peggy Green
Il knows of no control
Her name is written in my heart,
And craven on my sole
He ST. he'd in yain--she fouted him,
Her ,corn he deeply felt,
Like i1oWers killed by cruel frost,
lie soon began to rveh,
Now when she saw their love so true
To choose she knew no, which;
Three days she nothing did hut think
The fourth day saw her Stitch,
And now It was not long before


Uar heard the woetul news,
That Jenny Stitch his rival was,
standing in his shoes
His heart was broke, when he saw things
Had come TO such pass;
any days are numbered now !" sigh'd he.
Sand near me is my iassn
In vain to him the doctors did
Their pills and physic send:
lie failed apace-his eyes grew dim.
And nearer ward his end
'A.lack a-day" he cried, i" is She
To me forever lost
cannot-cannut give up Peg"
And then gave up the ghost
Now vi, Stitch and Mrs Stitch
Inc ieased in jo, and riches

to discharge to the remains OF my Grandfather
The last OF those melancholy personal duties, which
devolyed his relative, friend and Executor
and who, of all men living, loved him most. had
proposed myself in the discharge of this duty to
have strictly followed that form which he had inti-
mated 10 me- as being most agreeable to him,
simple atd unostrntatious index OF the spot where
his remains were deposited suited to the crcum
stances Of his family, OF stone; that the fu
tute proprietor might not be tempted to destroy il
Tor the value OF the materials on the grave plain
die or cube Of three feet without any nouldnpss
surmounted by an obelsk Of six feet, each of sim
gle stone. On the faces of the obsiisk. the fol-
lowing inscription, and not word more.


HERE WAS BURIED


THOMAS JEFFERSON,
Author OF the Declaration OF American IndepeRs
dence, of the Statutes of Virginia for Religious
Freedom, and Father Of the University Of Vir-
ginia.


On the die:


BoRN. ApRtL 2, l743, o. S.


DIED, JULY 4, 1926.
BY these, as testimonials that he had lived, he
desired most to be remembered. In compliance
with your very gratifying wishes upon the subjecss
aud knowing the long and cordial feelings of kind
ness which had existed between yourselves and my
excellent and beloved parent, l resign cheerfully
to your more skfu hands this last act of our per-
sonal services Accept for yourselves the assurance
OF my klndest esteem.


Very respectfully,


THO: J. RANDOLPH,
JOHN NJ. PERRr, and


JAMEs DINsMoRs, Esqrs.


Near the University.

.Niw Fork, Feb 6-sevcrsl respectable ind,id-
uals in this city have purchased Of land In
the island of Cuba. for the purpose OF forming
settlement there. and associated themselves under
The title Of the Company # .Noa. In order to faci
lilae their views they have applied to the Ltgish-
ture Of this state for act of incorporation under
The above title. We observe BY the Legislative
proceedings that their application has bees before
the House, where it has met with some opposition,
but as we think, under erroneous impressions as to
the objects of the company We understand from
coed authority, tha, the settlement at Moa is not
only patroniEed by the local authorities of Cuba.
but 10 made with express reference, and in conlor-
nifty to decree Of the King OF Spain, Of October
2lst, 1917, the title Of which explains its object
:" Real Cedula sobrs aumentar Ia pottacion biance
de Ia Ista de Cuba': that is. Royal Decree on
the subject Of increasing the trhite population of The
Island OF Cuba.''


Ono ground of opposition, as 1t appears by the
debate reported in the Albany papers, vas that The
granting Of the application would encourage negro
slavery. The views OF the association have been
entirely misconstrued. So far from this being the
fact, the company neither own, nor intend ever to
own single slave. The climate Of Moa is uneom-
monty temperate, and it has been proved by expo
rence that uhite man can pei iform bodily labor
there. with little danger to his health in this
state. One Of the principal objects of the Company
is to demonstrate by actual experiment that the
land can be cultivated uithout the labor Of btackss
and to set an example, which, if followed through
out the island will deprive The monsters who traffic
in human flesh, Of their principal market.


". T. GaS.


North West Passage - In letter from Mr..
Douglas, the botanist to DR.. Hooker, dat. d from
the Great Falls on the Columbia river, the 24th Of
March, 1923, there is the 10 lowing curious para.
graph respecting the North West Passage:


There is here Mr.. Macleod, who spent the
last Ave years at Fort Good Hope, on the Macken-
zie river. He informs me that it the natives with
whom he 10 perfectly acquainted. are worthy Of
credit there must be North West Passage. They
describe very large river that runs parallel With
The Mackenzie, and falls into the sea near Icy
Cape, at the mouth of which there is an establish
me nj on an island where ships come to trade. They
assert that the people there very wicked, having
hanged several of the natives 10 the rigging they
wear their boards long. Some rclianoe, should
think. may be laid on their satemen as Mr.. Macleod
showed US some Russian coins, combs, ard several
articles Of hardware, very different from those fur
nished by the British Company. MIR. Macleod
caused the natives to assemble last summer, tor the
purpose of accompanying him in his departure for
Hudson's Bay. The sea is said 10 be open alter
July. This gentieman's conduct affords striking
example of the effects of perseverance. In the
short space Of eleven months, he visited the Polar
Sea- and the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, undergo
ing such hardships and dangers as perhaps, were
never experienced by any other individual"
